contentrichtext.text: {{One source|date=April 2011}} [[Image:Uriah Forrest.jpg|thumb|200px|Uriah Forrest]] '''Uriah Forrest''' (1746 – July 6, 1805) was an [[United States|American]] statesman and military leader from [[Maryland]]. Forrest was born in [[St. Mary's County]] in southern Maryland. During the [[American Revolutionary War]], Forrest was injured and lost a leg in the [[Battle of Germantown]].<ref name="Ecker 1933, p. 12">Ecker (1933), p. 12</ref> Through his granddaughter, Alice Green, he is the great-grandfather of [[Agustín de Iturbide y Green|Don Agustín, Prince of Iturbide]], the heir of Emperor Maximilian I of Mexico and prince of the [[First Mexican Empire|First]] and [[Second Mexican Empire]]s. Uriah Forrest also is a direct male descendent of [[Thomas Forrest, Esq]] a Financier with the [[Virginia Company]] who came to the [[Jamestown, Virginia]] Colony on the [[History of the Jamestown Settlement (1607–1699)|Second Supply]] ship in 1608. After the war, he traveled to [[London]], but then returned to Maryland. In 1783, Forrest established a [[tobacco]] export business in [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]], with business partners [[Benjamin Stoddert]] and John Murdock.<ref name="Ecker 1933, p. 12"/> Forrest was also active in politics, representing Maryland as a delegate to the [[Continental Congress]] in 1787. He also served in the [[United States House of Representatives, Maryland District 3|third district]] of Maryland in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Congress]] from 1793 to 1794. He also served as mayor of the Town of George, now Georgetown, in 1791 when [[George Washington]] met with local landowners at [[Forrest-Marbury House|his home]] to negotiate purchase of the land needed to build the new capital city. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * {{cite book |title=A Portrait of Old Georgetown |year=1933 |publisher=Garrett & Massie, Inc. |author=Ecker, Grace Dunlop}} ==External links== *{{CongBio|F000282}} {{S-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{succession box | before=[[John F.
